bibl.title: Letter from [George A. Kellogg] to Albert E. Truby, February 18, 1941

div1.p: [Kellogg] discusses his meeting with Hench, as well as proposed changes to the Cornwell painting based on Hench's suggestions. He includes a list of questions for Truby concerning details that will appear in the painting.

div1.head: Letter from [George A. Kellogg] to Albert E. Truby, February 18, 1941
div1.opener:
JOHN WYETH & BROTHER
INCORPORATED
Dr. Philip F. Hench
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
February 18, 1941
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street,
San Francisco, Calif.
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
This past Thursday and Friday, Mr. D. J. Withington, and
myself, both of John Wyeth and Brother, Incorporated, Philadelphia,
spent some time with Dr. Philip F. Hench at which time he looked
over some sketches painted by Mr. Dean Cornwell in preparation for
our new painting, “The Conquest of Yellow Fever”. You may or may
not have heard of the series of paintings which John Wyeth and
Brother are sponsoring under the name of “Pioneers of American
Medicine”.

Dr. Hench had very kindly invited us to see him when he
had heard that the picture was in preparation. As it proved, he
had much valuable material for us to read and many splendid sugges-
tions on the production of the picture. In fact we, on his sugges-
tion, are going to have the locale changed from the patio of Dr.
Finley's home to the oursporch of the officers' quarters at Camp
Columbia. I believe that Dr. Hench will have written you before
you receive this letter. I took some photographs of the sketches
which I left with him before they were developed, so at the moment
I don't know whether I got anything or not.

The problem the artist is up against at the present in-
volves getting the answers to certain questions, which I am going
to ask you in this letter, hoping that you will be willing to help
us in this project.

list.item:
1. Were these buildings at Camp Columbia painted and if
so in what color?

2. Would you give us the approximate size of Dr. Lazear's
little note book, which played such a prominent part in influencing
Dr. Reed to continue the research?

3. When feeding the mosquitoes would Dr. Carroll and Dr.
Lazear have taken off their military coats and rolled up their shirt-
sleeves for it. If so, what type of shirt would they have been
wearing. Would it have been white or khaki color?
4. Were the army nurses in white uniforms?

5. Is it possible that Miss Clara Maas had been out at
Camp Columbia during the time that Carroll and Lazear were doing
their early experimental work.

div1.p:
I am asking this last question because it is possible
that the artist would like to have the relief of a woman's figure
in the picture in contrast to all the men, which will of necessity
have to dominate it.

Dr. Hench suggested that you might be willing to lend us
a copy of the portion of your diary which concerns Lazear's death
and the discovery of the note book. If you can do this, I am sure
it would be quite helpful to Mr. Cornwell.

For your information the completed painting will be
approximately four by six feet in size and will be reproduced in
full color for free distribution to physicians.
Any help that you can give us will be sincerely appreciated.

closer.signed:
JOHN WYETH & BROTHER, INC.
Advertising Director
